document.docTitle: Reinhardorhynchus soror Diez, Reygel & Artois 2021, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomy and phylogeny of Koinocystididae (Platyhelminthes, Kalyptorhynchia) with the description of three new genera and twelve new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material and distribution.
Observations on live specimens, whole mounted afterwards. Three whole mounts from Tombolo West ( 08¬∞48‚Äô05‚ÄùN ; 79¬∞33‚Äô15‚ÄùW ) (Type Locality), Taboga Island , Panama (
December 9, 2011
), one of which designated holotype ( USNM 1642508 ), the others in the USNM (1642509‚Äì1642510), from medium-coarse sand with ripple marks close to swash zone, small waves, salinity 28
‚Ä∞.

Etymology. Species name refers to its similarities with
R . beatrizae
sp. n .
Lat.
soror
: sister.

Diagnosis. Species of
Reinhardorhynchus
gen. n.
with a copulatory bulb encompassing a spiny cirrus and two distal hooks. Cirrus armed with triangular, ¬±5-Œºm-long spines. It also has a ¬±437-Œºm-long belt of spines, which shows three distinct regions: 1) a proximal part with curved and hook-shaped spines fused at their bases, the largest one ¬±57 Œºm long, the others measuring 6‚Äì40 Œºm, 2) a middle part with 3-Œºm-long spines, and 3) a distal, combshaped part armed with ¬±39-Œºm-long and triangular spines. The larger of the distal hooks curved, ¬±87 Œºm long and ¬±68 Œºm wide at its base; its base provided with a funnel-like, ¬±70-Œºm-long hook. Smaller hook ¬±59 Œºm long and ¬±59 Œºm wide at its base.

Description. The specimens are 1.5‚Äì2.2 mm long ( xÃÑ = 1.7 mm ; n = 3), translucent, with two rounded eyes ( Fig. 14A : e). The proboscis ( Fig. 14A : pr) is of the typical koinocystidid construction (see Brunet 1972 ; Karling 1980 ); it represents 15% of the body length in live specimens. The pharynx ( Fig. 14A : ph) has a diameter of 15% of the body length in live specimens and is located at 40‚Äì50%.

The testes ( Fig. 14A : t) are located rostral to the pharynx. The seminal vesicles ( Fig. 14A : sv) fuse just before entering the copulatory bulb. The male copulatory bulb is globular and 320‚Äì391 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 356 Œºm; n = 2). The prostate vesicle ( Fig. 14A : pv) opens into the armed cirrus. The cirrus is of the same structure as that of
R . beatrizae
sp. n .
The cirrus ( Fig. 14A : ci) is armed with triangular, 4‚Äì5-Œºm-long spines ( xÃÑ = 5 Œºm; n = 35) ( Fig. 14F : cis). The cirrus also includes a 437-Œºm-long belt of spines (n = 1) ( Fig. 14A : cir), which consists of three parts. The proximal part is provided with spines that are curved and hook shaped ( Fig. 14B, 14F : cps, 14G), the largest one 55‚Äì60 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 57 Œºm; n = 3) and the other ones 6‚Äì40 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 18 Œºm; n = 3). This proximal part forms a continuous 62‚Äì72-Œºm-long row ( xÃÑ = 66 Œºm; n = 3). The middle part forms a broad surface consisting of 3-Œºm-long spines ( Fig. 14F : cms) and measuring 109 Œºm (n = 1). The distal part is 129‚Äì135 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 132 Œºm; n = 2) and consists of a continuous comb-shaped row of spines ( Fig. 14C, 14F : cds). The spines in this part are 20‚Äì59 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 39 Œºm; n = 44) and increase in size from the most proximal one to the most distal one.

There are two large distal hooks. The larger one ( Fig. 14A & 14F : h 1, 14E ) is 84‚Äì89 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 87 Œºm; n = 3) and 63‚Äì77 Œºm wide at its base ( xÃÑ = 68 Œºm; n = 3), curved, and carries a funnel-like and 65‚Äì80 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 70 Œºm; n = 3) projection at its base ( Fig. 14E‚ÄìF : fh). This structure is straight, makes a ¬±90¬∫ angle with the main hook, and ends in a blunt tip. The hook proper is strongly curved and ends in a sharp tip. At its base, there is a small, more or less square and folded projection ( Fig. 14E : fp). The smaller hook ( Fig. 14A & 14F : h2, 14D) is 57‚Äì89 Œºm long ( xÃÑ = 59 Œºm; n = 3) and 54‚Äì62 Œºm wide ( xÃÑ = 59 Œºm; n = 3) at its base. The base of this hook is asymmetrical. The hook is slightly curved and ends in a sharp tip.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 14.
Reinhardorhynchus soror
sp. n.
. A, general organisation (from a live animal). B & G, proximal spines of the spiny row of the cirrus. C, distal spines of the spiny row of the cirrus. D, smaller hook. E, larger hook. F, sclerotised structures of the copulatory bulb. B‚ÄìG, from the holotype. All with proximal end toward top of figure.

subSubSection.paragraph: Vitellaria were not observed. The ovaries are oval shaped ( Fig. 14A : ov), located rostral to the copulatory bulb, with the oocytes organised in a row. The oviducts open into the female duct. The female duct opens into the receptacle bursa (terminology of Karling 1980 ) ( Fig. 14A : rb) through a strong sphincter. In a live specimen one embryo ( Fig. 14A : em), apparently not surrounded by a shell, was observed, suggesting the species is (ovo-)viviparous. The common gonopore ( Fig. 14A : cg) is located ventrally, at 90%.
